story.text: NEW YORK Jan 3 U.S. stocks inaugurated 2007 with strong gains on Wednesday after a drop in oil prices and a stronger-than-expected reading in a U.S. manufacturing gauge sparked optimism about the economy and corporate profits. The view that moderate economic growth would give the Federal Reserve little impetus to cut interest rates sent bond prices lower, erasing early gains. The dollar, meanwhile, rallied to two-month highs. The Institute for Supply Management (ISM) said its manufacturing index climbed to 51.4, above the 50 threshold that separates expansion in the sector from contraction. Oil prices fell as mild weather in the U.S. Northeast cut demand for fuel in the world's biggest heating oil market. U.S. crude CLc1 fell $2.41 to $58.65 a barrel. The Dow Jones industrial average .DJI was up 104.38 points, or 0.84 percent, at 12,567.53. The Standard & Poor's 500 Index .SPX was up 8.82 points, or 0.62 percent, at 1,427.15. The Nasdaq Composite Index .IXIC was up 34.78 points, or 1.44 percent, at 2,450.07. Shares of retailers Wal-Mart Stores Inc. (WMT.N) and Home Depot Inc. (HD.N) led gains. Shares of Wal-Mart rose after the world's largest retailer estimated over the weekend that its December same-store sales rose more than it had expected in the crucial holiday shopping period. Stock in home improvement retailer Home Depot advanced after the resignation of its chairman and chief executive revived takeover talk. ISM said its manufacturing index for December rose to 51.4 from a November reading of 49.5. "It's not huge, but the economy seems like it has firmed," said Robert Macintosh, chief economist at Eaton Vance Management in Boston. Shares of Wal-Mart rose 3.1 percent to $47.63, while shares of Home Depot gained 3.2 percent to $41.43. Before slipping at mid-morning, bond prices rose when the ADP National Employment Report showed private sector employers shed 40,000 jobs last month, the first contraction in private sector employment in nearly four years. The report flew in the face of consensus forecasts for a solid rise. Key data on U.S. employment are due on Friday from the U.S. Labor Department. Economists, according to a median estimate culled from a Reuters poll, expect that 110,000 new jobs were added to U.S. payrolls in December. In early afternoon, benchmark 10-year notes were flat on the day, yielding 4.68 percent, having erased earlier gains. Led by strong gains against European currencies including sterling, the euro and the Swiss franc, the dollar was set for its biggest rise in around six months against a basket of six major currencies =USD. The euro EUR= was trading down 0.8 percent on the day at $1.3175, while sterling tumbled more than 1 percent to $1.9485 GBP= in its biggest daily decline since July 2005. The dollar was up 0.7 percent at 119.63 yen JPY= after reaching as high as 119.65 on electronic trading platform EBS. Minutes from the U.S. Federal Reserve's most recent policy meeting due at 2 p.m. (1900 GMT) were expected to shed some more light on the likely outlook for interest rates. (Additional reporting by Caroline Valetkevitch, David McMahon, John Parry)
